head.title: Tar Heels Fight Off Maryland's Challenge

hedline.hl1: Tar Heels Fight Off Maryland's Challenge

block.p: North Carolina 95, Maryland 89
Derrick Phelps scored 9 of his 21 points in the final 2 minutes 12 seconds last night as No. 1 North Carolina held off a furious second-half rally by Maryland for a 95-89 victory in Chapel Hill, N.C.

The triumph gave the Tar Heels 20 victories for the 24th straight season and moved Carolina (20-3, 8-2 in the Atlantic Coast Conference) back into a first-place tie with No. 2 Duke. It also gave Dean Smith 27 20-victory seasons in his 33 years as coach.
North Carolina 95, Maryland 89
Derrick Phelps scored 9 of his 21 points in the final 2 minutes 12 seconds last night as No. 1 North Carolina held off a furious second-half rally by Maryland for a 95-89 victory in Chapel Hill, N.C.

The triumph gave the Tar Heels 20 victories for the 24th straight season and moved Carolina (20-3, 8-2 in the Atlantic Coast Conference) back into a first-place tie with No. 2 Duke. It also gave Dean Smith 27 20-victory seasons in his 33 years as coach.
Maryland (12-7, 5-5), which was in a first-place A.C.C. tie with Duke two weeks ago, has lost four in a row -- all league games.
Louisville 65, South Florida 50

Clifford Rozier scored 25 points and keyed a 17-6 run down the stretch as No. 7 Louisville pulled away to a 65-50 victory over South Florida in Tampa, Fla. The victory was the ninth straight for the Cardinals (19-2, 8-1 Metro Conference), who were playing their first game since Coach Denny Crum was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame.
Temple 51, Duquesne 49

Eddie Jones scored 24 points and Jason Ivey hit a short bank shot with six seconds left last night to give No. 8 Temple (17-3, 10-2 Atlantic 10 Conference) the victory in Philadelphia. Duquesne tied the game with 15 seconds left on a jumper by Kenya Hunter. Rick Brunson then found Ivey for the short shot and the victory.
Massachusetts 70 Rhode Island 64

Derek Kellogg scored 13 points, 7 of them in the final two minutes, and Lou Roe overcame an early injury to add 11 points, as No. 13 Massachusetts outlasted Rhode Island, 70-64, last night to remain undefeated in the Atlantic 10. Mike Williams, Marcus Camby and Dana Dingle each had 9 points for the Minutemen (18-4, 9-0). It was Williams's first appearance since being cleared to play by cardiac specialists after he collapsed during a game at Cincinnati on Jan. 27.
Arizona 77, Stanford 60

Khalid Reeves scored 33 points and had six 3-pointers as No. 16 Arizona held host Stanford to its fewest points of the season. Rebounding from last Saturday's 74-69 loss at Washington, Arizona claimed a 13th straight win over Stanford, which lost for just the second time in 11 home games this season. The other loss was to then-No. 1 U.C.L.A.
U.C.L.A. 79, Washington 76

Tynus Edney scored 22 points, including six free throws in the final three minutes, and Shon Tarver added 20 points as No. 9 U.C.L.A. rallied in the last four minutes to beat Washington in Los Angeles. Marquette 61, Cincinnati 60
Jim McIlvaine blocked 8 shots, scored 18 points and hit 2 free throws that gave visiting Marquette the victory, snapping a five-game losing streak to Cincinnati.
Iona 74, Niagara 63
Mikkel Larsen scored 22 points and Greg Barr added 21 as Iona snapped a five-game losing streak with the victory over Niagara in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game at Niagara Falls, N.Y.
Fairleigh Dickinson 83 Long Island U. 79

Tanner Robinson's 3-point play with 19 seconds left gave visiting Fairleigh Dickinson a 2-point lead and Dave Freeman added two free throws as the Knights (11-10, 7-6 Northeast Conference) won. BASKETBALL
